I suppose you could create a static reference to the TestResult and 
check it in you teardown, but that is a hack I would avoid unless 
this happens to you often. Just commenting out teardown and running 
the test in isolation works fine unless your system takes too long to 
build which is usually not the case these days.

-d
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Brian <br524@y...>" <br524@y...> wrote:
> I see in the TestResult class there's a method wasSuccessful().  
From
> within class that extends TestCase, I want to do something like 
this:
> 
>     public void tearDown()
>     {
>         TestResult result = createResult();
>         if( result.wasSuccessful() )
>         {
>             System.out.println( "Clearing database" );
>             clearDatabase( "1" );
>         }
>     }
> 
> The problem is that createResult() returns a new instance of
> TestResult, not the TestResult for the test that was just run.  Is
> there any way to accomplish what I'm trying to do?
> 
> Thanks,
> -Brian
